definitions.definition: a small group of musicians who play popular music together, often with a singer or singers

examples.text: a **rock/punk/jazz band **
He plays drums in a band that he formed with some friends.
The band is/are playing a gig in Liverpool tonight.
She's a singer with a band.
There's nothing like the excitement of seeing a **live band**.
her fellow **band members**
He formed a garage band with his friends.
He was accompanied onstage by his backing band.
They hired a Beatles tribute band to play at the reception.

definitions.definition: a group of musicians who play brass and percussion instruments

examples.text: a military band
We heard a band strike up in the park.
The band was/were playing and marching in time.

definitions.definition: a group of people who do something together or who have the same ideas, interests or achievements

examples.text: a band of outlaws/rebels
He persuaded a small band of volunteers to help.
A band of helpers was/were getting everything ready.
They are members of a growing band of enthusiasts.
The two men are part of a dwindling band of veterans.
He is one of a select band of top class players.
The young Irishman joined the elite band of Formula One drivers this week.

definitions.definition: a thin flat piece or circle of any material that is put around things, for example to hold them together or to make them stronger

examples.text: She always ties her hair back in a band.
All babies in the hospital have name bands on their wrists.
She wore a simple band of gold *(= a ring)* on her finger.

definitions.definition: a line of colour or material on something that is different from what is around it

examples.text: a white plate with a blue band around the edge
The light had expanded in a broad band across the sky.
Short-wave radio uses the 20–50-metre band.

definitions.definition: a range of numbers, ages, prices, etc. within which people or things are counted or measured

examples.text: the 25–35 age band
Which tax band do you fall into?

wordOrigin: noun senses 4 to 7 late Old English (in the sense of something that restrains), from Old Norse, reinforced in late Middle English by Old French bande, of Germanic origin; related to bind. noun senses 1 to 3 late Middle English: from Old French bande, of Germanic origin; related to banner.
